Situation1: Their partner faces a tough decision at work and seeks advice and encouragement.
Situation2: Two travelers with several suitcases ask for help loading and plan to split the fare
Story: I glanced at my phone as I waited at the taxi stand, my husband’s name lighting up the screen. His message was long, anxious—he was facing a tough decision at work and needed my advice. I could almost hear his voice, hoping I’d reassure him, help him sort through the mess. I started to type a reply, but just then, two travelers approached, dragging heavy suitcases behind them. “Can you help us load these? We’ll split the fare,” one said, already opening the trunk. I forced a smile, knowing I needed to be professional, efficient, and courteous. My mind raced: my husband needed me, but so did these customers. If I took too long texting, I’d seem inattentive, maybe even rude. If I focused on the travelers, I’d leave my husband alone with his worries. My heart tugged in two directions—toward the man I loved, needing comfort, and toward the job that paid our bills, demanding my full attention. I stood there, phone in hand, suitcase in the other, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in.
